I've always been curious. What do these people think of their colleagues that disagree with them?
If some scientists and epidemiologists say "Covid is nothing to be too concerned with" and others say it's "a big threat", who's to say which is correct?

If one is considered wrong, does that mean their qualifications should be called into question? And if their qualifications are questioned, doesn't that mean the institution in which those qualifications were obtained should also be reviewed? And if the Institution is handing out qualifications wrongly or to students not actually qualified, who's to say that all students of this institution shouldn't also be called into question?

6 months later takeaways:

- Astonishing time capsules only have to be buried for 6 months.
- "Things are changing so fast!" and still are.
- "Being in quarantine is really hard!" and still is.
- "I'll have to wait a couple of weeks to see my friends." Have you seen them yet?
- Dianne reiterates that being lax could contribute to a possible Second Wave with the general mindset at that time that lockdown could make a return to normal possible. Yeah, that unlikely second wave nuisance. We'll be on top of things by then!
- Delayed treatment for non-COVID-19 cases was already having an impact in mid-April.
- Arti describes the potential for public lack of trust arising from disappointment of low efficacy vaccines and pretty much treats this as the only issue of trust at this early time. Anecdotally, after working 4 months in a COVID hospital, it appears that a high percentage of people are naturally immune to it, or at least unlikely to get it. No one in my department got sick treating COVID patients. No one in the ER got sick either. We're talking about several hundred people - zero cases. And many of us have had antibody tests and all have come back negative so far. It is a very strange disease, that is for sure.

My humble experience has taught me that vulnerable people (elderly, compromised immune systems, those with obesity & diabetes) should be protected. Measures need to be taken to isolate these people. Everyone else - go back to your normal life! You have very little to be concerned about. Real disease, can be bad some susceptible people, but not a reason to shut down the world.
The hospitals are empty.

It might have been helpful to ask your ER RN friend how the disease is NOT like the flu. There are many SERIOUS SYMPTOMS. Make no mistake: it has a number of flu-like symptoms, but It is NOT the flu. Doctors tried to treat it LIKE THE flu. They tried to do protocols like those for serious S.O.B., intubation, and breathing machine treatments, but found that doing these things often did more harm than good--totally the opposite to what they were used to. They found Pt's w/ super low O2 sat levels being fine--saying they were feeling fine--but in all their training and experience told them that a pt w/ THAT low a score should be in crises.  current protocols would say if your Pt's O2 sat lvls fall bellow  a certain lvl,  you need to intubate. And at another lvl put them on breathing  ventilators. Do that's what they would do w/ Covid Pt's--and those actions made things worse---not better; again just the opposite of what their experience taught them. Lots of things weren't making sense. They would have people seem to get better, so they would be released, then days later,  Pt's would crash; Pt's would have strokes & heart attacks who had no business having those things. Doctors were very confused and realized they need to treat it like a new  disease. There are apparently cascade like effects during  severe episodes of the disease--especially w/ Pt's w/ underlying co-morbitities like  diabetes, obesity, asthma, chronic bronchitis, and other respiratory diseases, kidney, heart disease, hypertension, and who knows, possibly other inflamatory related diseases--they DONT know.  But the bottom line is that many Pt's w/ other probs like these are at serious risk if they catch Covid as the virus may speed-up or exasurbate the irritation and inflammation of infected tissues that are effected by said comiebidity.  Clotting mechanisms can be triggered--thus the heart attacks and strokes,   Cytokine storms give way to irritation and inflammation of tissues affected by asthma / bronchitis---triggering pneumonia for example..Although I have a little training in allied health,   I am NOT a doctor, so I may have gotten my facts wrong in some cases. Do NOT take what I have said as Gospel. Understanding of this disease is changing by the day--which is a good thing. The other good thing is that many people dont have bad symptoms at all. Some, no symptoms at all. The bad news is they can easily spread the disease to you and me while not knowing they are actively shedding the virus. That's why it's important to follow CDC guidelines. Wash hands thoroughly and often, social distance, etc.

If i hear "a second wave" one more time as it relates to the US i'm going to rip out the last few hairs i have left. In order to have a "second wave" you need to have finished the "first wave" first!  That means cases/deaths rise and rise, reach a peak, then plateau for a time, then go down and down until there are only a scattering of cases/deaths, have a lull, and then the rise starts again. The US is at one of two places, either the plateau stage or it has not yet reached the peak. And the weight of the evidence is leaning heavily towards the latter. And if the US continues to push opening up, there will no longer be any question that the US has not yet reached its peak and almost guarantee a second wave will never happen. If everyone gets the infection in the first wave there won't be anyone left for a second one. Provided of course that long term immunity is acquired after recovery, which is not exactly certain at this point.  It seems to me that years from now when people look back at the graph showing the course of the infections, May 2020 will just be a teeny tiny insignificant sideways movement near the bottom of the graph, less than a tenth or twentieth of the way from the ultimate peak. But what do i know, i'm just using my education (MSc and MPH) and experience working as an epidemiologist for the last 40 plus years (now retired for three years) in dozens of countries around the globe to inform my opinions. It would be nice if i could use only hopes and dreams and could just wish it all away then the future would look so much nicer! But that damn thing called reality, with science and math and facts backing it up, keeps getting in the way.

Excellent video Dianna. I hope your viewers take this more seriously. I have been very lucky. Laughing while saying "sure it is scary" underlined the situation for me more than a calm serious "yes" would have done. That's a strong introduction.

I understand, ICU work always has a higher risk, COVID-19 is not the only infectious disease patients could have. You must be aware when specializing as an ICU nurse or - to give another example - palliative care what you're dealing with in risks and experiences. Still, when I relate this to a report I saw about a NY hospital ending up with more than 50% infected nurses, that's surely not what you sign for when picking that career. You'd be right to assume enough PPE always is there for you, for example.

And it makes one mad about a government that completely failed to make use of the defense production act to ensure sufficient stock of PPE earlier. And I admit, it's not a law I knew about beforehand, but when you learn Trump already made use of it for military purposes, that's removing the last bit of understanding for not being able to deal perfectly with an unprecedented situation.

I just want to point that my country has introduced some improvements in dealing with severe cases. The first was later intubation, holding on it for longer tends to give better outcomes.
The second one seems to be recent and it involves using small quantities of ozone (O3) mixed with the oxygen line. It both helps with oxygenation and as disinfectant. Some patients improve so dramatically that they avoid intubation.

There seems to be very intriguing relation between this virus and the blood.
Usually even asymptomatic people have low oxygen levels that make check with light based clip-on gadgets quite viable. But that's not all.
Autopsy of patients have revealed a lot of small clots, so now doctors are administering light doses of anti-coagulants in critical patients.

As a Pathologist (i.e. lab director), I'm supper happy to hear the words sensitivity and specificity mentioned. However, I think we need to take the next step to positive and negative predictive value, i.e. if the test is +, do I have the disease and if the test is -, do I not have the disease. This is what patients and doctors really want to know. So what is the link between these related #'s? Prevalence, or in Lab Medicine we often use the term "pre-test probability." What does this mean? If we test people who are not likely to have the disease, then most of the + test results will be false-positive and conversely, if we test people who are highly not likely to have the disease, then most of the - test results will be false-negatives. Here's Dr. Hannah Fry and Matt Parker explaining this concept to school-age children at the Royal Institute https://youtu.be/vBPFaM-0pI8 In the end, test results are only as good as the person who actually interprets them. Thanks again for this excellent interview video. Stay safe everyone.
